185954234.review:
The Street Fighter 4 series is what really got me into competitive fighting games outside of the Super Smash Bros. scene for the first time. During the vanilla Street Fighter 4 and Super Street Fighter 4 days, I mostly played casually, both online and at arcades.

When Ultra came out and finally had every character available on disc with no DLC nonsense, I started to really look back and appreciate what Street Fighter 4 did, while also noticing some of the flaws in the series.

At its core, it’s classic Street Fighter—six buttons, neutral-heavy gameplay, different character archetypes, all that good stuff. The main gimmicks of SF4 are kind of hit-or-miss for me, though. The Focus Attack is a fair and balanced way to deal with projectiles, and honestly, it’s better than how SF5 and SF6 handle anti-projectile mechanics. That said, having Ultras separate from Supers feels like a mistake. It leads to spammy gameplay. I get that Ultras are supposed to be comeback mechanics, but after playing SF5 and SF6, I feel like characters having multiple Supers just flows better.

For better or worse, this was the last Street Fighter game to have a more traditional arcade mode for telling character stories. Sure, it’s kind of limited—only two or three cutscenes per character—but looking back, it’s refreshing to have that classic console fighting game story experience all wrapped up in one package for every character. Especially when you consider how hit-or-miss the story and arcade modes have been in SF5 and SF6.

One thing I’ve been messing around with more is Ultra Street Fighter 4’s Omega Mode. I already thought the ability to play characters based on specific patches—vanilla SF4, Super, and Ultra—was a cool feature, but Omega Mode takes it further. It feels like a test bed for what they could get away with in SF5, and it’s fun. Especially considering how SF5 phased out invincible reversals, I’ve come to appreciate Omega Mode as a way to still enjoy fun gimmicks without losing core mechanics like uppercuts or DPs, which are a huge part of Street Fighter characters.

Overall, it’s a shame that Ultra Street Fighter 4 doesn’t have rollback netcode, especially since basically every other mainline entry does now. But it’s still one of the most content-rich Street Fighter games (without DLC) ever. It stays true to the traditional formula while sprinkling in just a few gimmicks—unlike SF5 and SF6, which feel like they’ve gone off the rails by changing so much about major characters and leaning hard into the modern rushdown-only meta.

184753505.review:
Le jeu qui a fait revivre la communauté de versus fighting.
J'y ai passé des milliers d'heures entre la version PS3-PC et les version Vanilla qui avait un cast restreint, SSF4 qui ajoute une bonne vingtaine de personnage, la version AE et Ultra qui font toujours office de patch d'équilibrage payant (Ultra ajoute quand même l'Ultra W et la Red Focus Attack).
Jeu à la fois simple et exigeant et que je trouve bien mieux avec le recul que les opus suivants. C'est peut être un avis biaisé mais le jeu de footsies, de distance, de punition, la variété des personnages, c’était vraiment tout une époque. Oui c'est un avis biaisé sachant que je ne joue plus tellement a ce genre de jeu.

On se rappellera a tout jamais des vidéo du Tougeki en 80 parties de Ken Bogard sur Youtube en 360p bien encodé avec le fiak haha. Une époque révolue qui m'émeut ! BRING. ME. BACK !

184643828.review:
This game bring me back.

Ultimate Street Fighter 4 is the definitive love letter to fighting game fans, delivering smooth mechanics, a deep roster of 44 characters, and just the right amount of "Hadouken!" chaos. Mini stories and cut-scenes for each character. Skill based Mini games, and so much more! 

I don't play it often anymore.  But I MILKED this game HARD when it first launched on other platforms. As for this version specifically, its amazing. Runs on ROG ally And Steamdeck with no Stutters, or Slowdown. Everything is pretty optimized and intact from what I can remember.

it's fair to note the the multiplayer has been dead for quite some time. (heck, "Multiplayer" is not even a store tag). But this game is an amazing once in awhile Nostalgic trip, as well as a great couch co-op choice! 

maybe not full price, but i def recommend at sale price

184596878.review: 先说结论，非常推荐！！虽然这个主号显示只玩了半个小时，但是我在家庭号上这三天就玩了超过15个小时，体验真是太棒了！买之前就特意做了功课，选择了4代，而不是5代。网上都说4比5好，人也比5多。特效做的好，都是水墨画，很有意思！因为以前从没玩过，所以一直在探索着玩，只玩过街霸2，区别还是挺大的。现在技能，EX大招以及UC复仇技能都搞清楚了。但是看他们变身成小红人和小白人不会弄，有知道的大神不？希望给我帮助，先谢谢了！ 这个游戏最大的缺点，我发现是键盘的原始按钮设置，太反人类了，全靠自己重新自定义。然后就舒服多了，哈哈！

184246035.review:
Ultra Street Fighter IV foi um marco incrível pra franquia. Lembro bem quando lançaram, e a mudança visual foi uma coisa que me chamou muito a atenção. Um upgrade certeiro e que só deixou o jogo ainda mais atrativo.

A mecânica? Ah, continua com aquele feeling clássico que todo fã de Street Fighter conhece. Os movimentos, os combos, tudo bem no estilo old-school, mas com um toque modernizado. Agora, confesso: achei alguns personagens completamente overpower. Seth, por exemplo... Olha, enfrentar esse bicho usando a IA é de arrancar os cabelos! Ele só defende, anula tudo que você tenta fazer, e ainda solta golpes que parecem impossíveis de parar. Pra quem não tem o costume de jogar jogos de luta, pode ser bem frustrante. Já pros pro-players, é só mais um dia no escritório.

Apesar disso, é um jogo fantástico, com gráficos que impressionam, uma quantidade de personagens pra todos os gostos e muito conteúdo pra explorar. Ultra Street Fighter IV consegue ser fiel à sua essência e, ao mesmo tempo, trazer algo fresco pra galera nova.

Recomendo demais pra quem é fã de pancadaria digital e curte jogos como Injustice, Mortal Kombat ou a própria franquia Street Fighter. Um clássico que vale ter na sua coleção!
